div1.p: I wish you had all the letters I have thought to you. We've had the flu here--both Bower and I, though I haven't had flu for years. This kind is treacherous; don't you get it. In fact, don't let anyone with a sore throat anywhere near you. We didn't have to go to the hospital as many of our friends did, but we were flattened at home.

Did Robin tell you I talked with him while you were in the hospital? I hoped to catch Hilda, but she is a busy lady. It was nice to talk to Robin; I still can't believe he is so completely grown up. Just before Myrtle wrote that you had recovered and were in Lincoln I dreamed about you. I knew you had been quite ill, and that you were better, but I was still uneasy. In the dream you were talking to a small group of people, and as usual when I dream about you, you were in the center of the light, as if you were in a spotlight. You were talking animatedly, and then I heard you laugh and woke up thinking, "John's all right." And then Myrtle's letter same. I hope you are still walking around the block when you have a mind to.

I am sending in the same mail a letter to you, really a birthday card, from a little boy in Eugene to whom you are the center of the universe. He is the son of one of my students, and he is something like you--that is, he's a genius. He went out the top of all the IQ tests and the state board is hunting an expert to try to test him. Meanwhile he is by special arrangement taking courses in the university along with his elementary school work, and he is looking for a math book that will teach him enough to undrerstand Einstein. I'm sending along a poem he wrote that he is willing for you to see. This reminds me so happily of the things I know about your early life that I thought you would be interested.

Also, I want to tell you about the biography. I have sent it to Missouri Press, and they warned me that it would be a month or two. I also sent them a copy of the letter from Angus Cameron at Knopf because it speaks well of the book and apologizes inain a way for not publishing it--too specialized. I do want to

see it in print, and you are right that it doesn't compete with your book. It does something you can't do for your own work; it pitches at the scholars who eventually cement poetry and prose into permanency. I find more and more young people who light up when your name is mentioned. The public is more than ready; words to the critics are now the step. I hope you will keep me up to date, because in the final editing I can add to the last chapter. I will put the President's letter in, and anything else you do in the meantime. I get the same feeling of inspiriting astonishment when I think about your life and your work that struck me when I first started. I am also getting at the letters gradually. It's a dreadful job of selection.

Do please take care of yourself in the cold weather. And when you feel like writing, toss me a line to say you're all right and still love me. I'll have an Olympia beer for you by proxy. Regards to the family and to Myrtle and J.D. I'm sending this letter to Lincoln because I don't know which circle you are illuminating at the moment. Perhaps I'll dream again.
